newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee futures charge higher, eye $1,800.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee futures charge higher, eye $1,800.

text.p: LIFFE robusta coffee futures charged higher on continued fund and industry buying with benchmark July finishing at the highest level since mid-March.
Traders said further gains were on the cards as roasters still have much price-fixing to do.

July ended Thursday $27 up at $1,780 a tonne, the previous resistance, after a ceiling at $1,785. Traders said the contract now looked set to challenge the next hurdle at $1,800, followed by the double top at $1,815 and $1,820 -- the two recent highs.
The robusta market rose for the fourth day in a row as hedge funds and roasters made an aggressive comeback after a lull. During that period, July alone gained some 13 percent.
Traders said London's advance came without much support from New York.
"For the first time, London didn't take too much notice of New York," said one.
New York jumped on Thursday on news port workers in Santos, Brazil, stopped work due to a salary delay. But traders in London said the stoppage was likely to be short-lived.
"Furthermore, there's not much coffee to be shipped," said one.
Arbitrage trading against New York regained lustre after a long spell as robusta prices began to stir. July/July arbitrage stood at 135 cents a lb by the close.

The upward momentum in London was also speeded by lack of aggressive origin offers. Indonesian sellers are sidelined either because of a local holiday in the country or are expecting much higher levels.
Volume reached just 6,774 lots by the close. --Jalil Hamid, London newsroom +44 171 542 4985
